contextId.information: This idiom means "was trying to kill you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is one of the strongest oaths David could swear, as Yahweh is the witness. AT: "I swear on the life of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This phrase means "a relative." AT: "we are related to you" or "we are of the same family" - (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: we are your flesh and bone

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means Yahweh spoke. "Yahweh spoke his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "with you" means that Yahweh has helped and blessed David. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means the person will be David's descendant. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: one who will come out from your body

contextId.information: Here the word "sent" means that she sent a messenger. She sent him to tell David that she was pregnant. AT: "she sent a messenger to David to tell him that she was pregnant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: she sent and told David; she said, "I am pregnant."

contextId.information: Here the word "sent" means that David sent a messenger. AT: "Then David sent a messenger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

David was asking if Joab and the army were well and about the progress of the war. AT: "if Joab was well, if other soldiers were well, and how the war was progressing" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: how Joab was, how the army was doing, and how the war was going

contextId.information: Possible meanings for the phrase "go down" are 1) Uriah's house was located at a lower elevation than the king's palace or 2) Uriah's house was of lesser importance than the king's palace. AT: "Go to your house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Possible meanings of the word "down" are 1) Uriah's house was located at a lower elevation than the king's palace or 2) Uriah's house was of lesser importance than the king's palace. See how you translated the similar phrase "down to your house" in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:11:06|11:8]]. AT: "to his house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here the word "sent" means that he sent a messenger to get her and bring her to him. AT: "David sent a messenger to her to bring her home" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: David sent and took her home

contextId.information: The phrase "born to you" means that it is David's baby. AT: "your child who will be born" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the child who is born to you

contextId.information: This is an idiom used to get people's attention. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is a request for her to serve food to him personally. AT: "and have her serve it to me herself ... she may serve it to me to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: and eat it from her hand ... I may eat from her hand

contextId.information: This means that Tamar made the bread in front of him. AT: "in front of him" or "in his presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is a phrase used to draw someone's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "take something to heart" means "to worry about it." AT: "worry about this report" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that the servant was watching for enemies while guarding at the city wall. AT: "who was guarding" or "who was guarding at the city wall" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom which means to kill. AT: "kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. The king was giving her permission to continue speaking. AT: "You may speak to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the idiom "to hand over" means to deliver out of someone's control. AT: "to deliver his servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"As surely as you are alive." Here the woman compares the certainty of what David has said to the certainty that he is alive, to emphasize how true his statement is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "found favor" is an idiom which means to be approved of by someone. The word "sight" is a metonym which refers to what the king thinks. AT: "you are pleased with me" (UDB) or "you have approved of me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I have found favor in your sight

contextId.information: This word is used here as an idiom to add emphasis, strengthening what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that he sent a messenger to go get Ahithophel and bring him back to him. AT: "he sent a messenger to go get Ahithophel who was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to cause disaster to happen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the word "keep" means to care for. AT: "to care for the palace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here this word is used to draw someone's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the phrase "leave him alone" means to not stop him from what he is doing. AT: "Do not stop him from cursing me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Leave him alone and let him curse

contextId.information: This means to purposefully go to where he is and then to attack. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to make sure that you do something. AT: "be sure to" or "make sure that you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The idiom "such and such" is used in the place of information that is already know by the reader. Here it refers to what Ahithophel advised Absalom in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:17:01|17:1-3]]. This information can be stated clearly. AT: "has advised that Absalom send him with an army to attack you now" (See:  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: has given such and such advice

contextId.information: He prepared for his death by telling his family what to do after he died. AT: "he prepared for his death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here this word is used to draw a person's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "touching" refers to "harming." AT: "No none must harm" or "Do not harm" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to oppose. AT: "opposed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This word is used here to draw someone's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen, the king is weeping" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that David sent a messenger to Zadok and Abiathar. AT: "sent a messenger to Zadok and to Abiathar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: sent to Zadok and to Abiathar

contextId.information: This means "to remember." AT: "remember" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"To take something to heart" means to think about something seriously or to be bothered by it. AT: "not be bothered by it" or "forget about it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This phrase "put to death" means to be killed or executed. AT: "Will any man be killed" or "Will I order any man to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Will any man be put to death

contextId.information: This means to do what you think is right. AT: "do what you believe to be the right thing to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: do what is good in your eyes

contextId.information: Here the phrase "to keep" means to take care of. AT: "to take care of the palace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that they were not allowed to leave the house. AT: "they were shut inside the house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
To be "for" someone means to support them. AT: "he who supports David" or "he who is loyal to David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "was over" refers to having authority over a group of people. AT: "Joab had authority over ... Benaiah son of Jehoiada had authority over ... Adoram had authority over" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Joab was over ... Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over ... Adoram was over

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means Yahweh spoke. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:07:03|7:3]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
